item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Palmiz, post:20, topic:426288”][quote author=MistaBigBoss link=topic=528982.msg3860156#msg3860156 date=1324608152]

[/quote]
I’ll just post this link here in case mr “I’m gonna maek teh next call of duty” forgot.

@the op.

I was going to be nice, and still will. Yes, I could accuse you of being a troll and I could have missed some form of inside joke. But I’ll take Poe’s law in consideration and just say STFU.
You asked a question, the people here answered, you didn’t like the answer, you started flaming the very people you trusted enough to ask. Notice the problem?

I’ll be blunt since I’ve seen this question so many times on other boards.
I’ll base it on the fact that you have no programming experience. You are welcome to correct me if I’m wrong.

YOU DO NOT HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE TO MAKE A MMO, FORGET IT

YOU DO NOT HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE TO MAKE A MMO, FORGET IT

YOU DO NOT HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE TO MAKE A MMO, FORGET IT

So. Now when it’s out in the air.

I lack the elitism of the other posters and finds nothing wrong in “Game Developer Software”. They are great if you just want to make a semi-complex game (I’ve used both). Lot of indie-devs use them. Daniel Remar’s IJI was made in Game maker. All of Kaktus’ games are made in Game Maker/Construct. I think Cave Story was made in Game Maker.

Both Game Maker and Construct does have onlinesupport.

BUT

You will NOT be able to make a MMO in them. You just won’t.

So. You want the right direction for MMO-city?
Game Maker/Construct is decent for beginners. You will at least learn some Game Logic and they have built in support for GML/Python so they will introduce you to some basic programming in an enviroment where things actually will happen on the screen.

The alternative is to just learn programming directly. Someone recomended C/C++. I do not. My university started with Java (with Slick2D or just LWJGL for gamedevelopment. But Haskell is a decent choice too (it’s not really game friendly though). Action Script 3 is a good starting point with the right library (Flixel or FlashPunk), but you won’t be able to do a non-farmville-like MMO with it. I’ve never touched Unity so I’m going to say:

Start with C# and XNA. It has decent performance, good documentation, an active community, and some good tutorials from Microsoft™. Visual Studio Express was free last time i checked, so thats a plus.

Just remember:
You will make shitty games for a lot of years. I started with C++ for like 7-10 years ago (I’ve never been dedicated/serious enough to do anything though) and I still make shitty games. Don’t start making your dream game. Make a lot of clones of simple games. Start with pong, go to snake, then breakout, Luna Lander, tetris, Super Mario etc.

I repeat. Your first games will suck without doubt, there is no point in wasting a good idea in a bad game.

And thats just the programming bit, then there is math…

You’ll need lot of math för a 3D game (you will do fine with some basic trigonometry for basic 2D).

Good Luck and Have fun. Don’t get disencouraged by the harsh words. Use it as a reality check and set up realistic goals.

Edit: I’ll not even talk about networking. It’s a field of voodoo and black magic. Half of the practitioners turns insane and the other half are child eating-atheist-muslim-terrorist-communist mexicans. True story.[/quote]I’m not going to read all of that but what I said in my OP was:

I have 2 years time to complete this engine because of the fact that 2 years is what is left for me to go to DAE (Digital Arts and Entertainment). This engine will become very handy in the future.

I will also probably assemble a team together for when the engine is completed, and make the next Call of Duty.

Meaning that, in the future, when I’m actually studying real game development, and the engine is completed, and I have a professional game development team, I’ll make a game like Call of Duty.

great, you read my post and understand it, so I can see that you are a lot more interested than I thought you were.

Those are APIs specifically made for helping people write games. If you didn’t use an already-made API, you’d be stuck with reinventing the wheel, even though some companies actually write their own, but only because they are professionals and doing it for a purpose other than it being already there and you don’t want to use it.

SFML is a great way to start for newbies. It was written in C++, and it is object-oriented. It is also faster than Allegro, and faster than SDL without the use of OpenGL rendering. It has a graphics core, a sound core, a system core, and a window core. Each of these were specifically written to help you write a game, rather than writing these all by yourself, which would literally take years of research and development for a starter. If you ever decide to use one of those APIs, I’d suggest donating to them for their help.

for more in-depth information: http://www.sfml-dev.org/

hopefully you’ll review that website when you are comfortable.

item.title: Game Developer Software
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

using software to make games isn’t really good practice, and you don’t get a whole lot out of it, for you, or your game. you are limited to what you can and cannot do. on the plus side, your game may be a bit better than what you could do with a programming language and a graphics library. the cons outweigh the pros, so i’d suggest (don’t just take it from me, ask anybody) writing simple games with a programming language such as java or c++ with a graphics, sound, and input library of your choice.

here are some portable full game development APIs, meaning they handle input, sound, graphics, text, raw rendering, or anything else your game needs. you can write engines, frameworks, or a simple unreusable pong clone if you wish:

SFML
SDL
Allegro
DirectX

i don’t use java for game development, but if you want to, there’s slick2d and i’ve heard really good things about this.

I believe you can use java with SDL and SFML. I also believe you can do the same with C#. Though you can use XNA with c#.
